newsitem.title: UK: Euro crude outlook - Dated down, other grades up.
newsitem.headline: Euro crude outlook - Dated down, other grades up.

text.p: Difficult refining economics and an awkward transatlantic arbitrage will keep European crude fundamentals tilted in buyers' favour next week, traders said.
But while differentials for leading Atlantic Basin crude Dated Brent will struggle, other North Sea grades might stage something of a recovery.
"Dated versus September will have to come off," said one major oil company trader.
"The (U.S.) arbitrage looks open for forward dates but not for prompt cargoes. We need lower numbers for the arb to work and I think that's what we'll probably get."
Brent for September 3-5 traded at Sept paper less five cents on Friday, though most dealers valued it nearer parity.
Heavily backwardated paper markets mean this week's lower differentials for other North Sea grades are unlikely to fall further.
"The fact the backwardation is so steep means the grade premia are valuable," said a trader. "They appear to have bottomed out at these levels."
Prompt early September grades had been all but cleared out by Friday, leaving the path clear for better values, he said.
U.K. Forties on Friday fetched Dated Brent plus 28 cents and Norway's Oseberg and Statfjord were pegged around plus 25-30 cents.
But sickly refining margins, on the mend by the end of the week, led by fuel oil and gas oil, were still keeping a lid on refinery buying.

A few refiners this week in Britain, Sweden, France and Italy announced run cuts, totalling about 150,000 barrels per day (bpd), to combat poor margins. Expectations of a heavy European autumn refinery maintenance schedule might also begin to tell next week on crude purchasing patterns, traders said.

Sour Urals in the Mediterreanean, at Brent less 90 cents cif Med, was showing little sign of a recovery despite buying from northern Europe and the U.S. which cleared at least three prompt cargoes in recent days.
"The first decade (of September) looks quite bad. We'll be seeing things sliding further," said one trader.
West African grades, consistently stronger in recent weeks than their North Sea and Mediterranean counterparts, were finding support from more Asian buying, despite refinery run cuts in the east.
Shipments east out of West Africa for September are set to run at about 500,000 bpd, roughly in line with August sales.
An apparently unattractive Brent/Dubai spread has not deterred buyers, mainly because regional benchmark Tapis has been running at such a high premium.

Differentials for Nigerian grades were still benefitting from a change in NNPC marketing policy which for the past two month has seen whole month loading nominations posted 30 days ahead. "It's been a success because it's given the market added flexibility," said a trader.
